rename.to: Bug: Unexpected Verdicts for the Rule "no-control-regex"

body:
Hi @watuwo, thanks for the issue!

This works as intended. This rule reports hex and unicode escape sequences as well as raw characters that represent control characters.

> As a rationale of the rule https://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-control-regex says: "These characters are rarely used in JavaScript strings so a regular expression containing these characters is most likely a mistake".

By "strings" it means strings on which the regular expression will be used, not regex pattern strings. The rationale is that any of \u0000-\u001F is more likely a typo than an intention to match that character because most of those characters rarely appear in strings, while those that are common have shorter escape sequences like `\t` and `\n`.

We should clarify this in the documentation, I'll work on that.

Thanks for the feedback and the clarification. Adapting the documentation will let people enable/disable the rule with more confidence.

*Personally* I would have preferred the rule to work according to my initial expectations. I feel like accidentally dropping a backslash is more likely something I would do than accidentally matching a control character. I can understand that other people have other use cases / priorities / deamons. I can understand if you don't want to change the eslint code for that.

When adapting the documentation: there is also a short explanation of the rule at https://eslint.org/docs/rules/ ("disallow control characters in regular expressions"). I don't know whether this should be changed (and if yes, to what).

> I feel like accidentally dropping a backslash is more likely something I would do than accidentally matching a control character. 

Dropping that backslash is not a bug. It results in a pattern with the character's code point, but it works the same as the pattern with an escape sequence for that character.

```js
new RegExp('\t').test("\t"); // true
new RegExp('\\t').test("\t"); // true
new RegExp('\u0009').test("\t"); // true
new RegExp('\\u0009').test("\t"); // true
new RegExp('\x09').test("\t"); // true
new RegExp('\\x09').test("\t"); // true
```

What doesn't look consistent in the behavior of this rule is reporting `new RegExp('\t')`. It's due to intent to report code such as `new RegExp('<TAB>')`, but since the rule only examines the pattern (string value) and doesn't map the pattern back to the original string literal, I believe the reporting of `new RegExp('\t')` is more an implementation side effect than an intent.

I agree, these examples are not errors. It would just have been a matter of personal taste (beeing consistent with `new RegExp('\\x2A')` where `new RegExp('\x2A')` would be an error). Of course `'\\x2A'` has nothing to do with control characters and I would not expect this rule to help me here.

Now knowing that `'\\u0009'` and `'\\x09'` were rejected on purpose, I have deactivated the rule. I am perfectly fine with that.

issue.title: docs: clarify no-control-regex rule

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.
